title: Ash Wednesday: The Sentence of Mortality
meditation: The imposition of ashes on Ash Wednesday shatters our denial of death and serves as a stark reminder of our mortality due to sin. In the act of receiving ashes, we embrace God's just sentence on the human race while looking to the cross-the very instrument by which the Son of God took that judgment upon Himself to redeem us.
prayer: Almighty and everlasting God, who hates nothing that You have made and forgives the sins of all those who are penitent: Create and make in us new and contrite hearts, that we, worthily lamenting our sins and acknowledging our wretchedness, may obtain from You, the God of all mercy, perfect remission and forgiveness; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord.

title: Thursday after Ash Wednesday: The Threefold Coming
meditation: Lent is a penitential season where we meditate on the threefold coming of Christ: His lowly coming in the flesh to save, His spiritual coming in our hearts today through the Word, and His final return to judge the quick and the dead. We pray for grace to welcome Him aright, lest through vanity or unbelief we drive His salvation away from us.
prayer: O Lord Jesus, You have again entered into our midst in the new church-year by granting to us again the proclamation of Your Word. Grant us grace to welcome You aright, and guide us, that through our deliberations Your name may be hallowed, Your kingdom come, and Your will be done.

title: Friday after Ash Wednesday: True Abstinence
meditation: While fasting and bodily preparation are good external disciplines, the Christian should desire to satisfy the soul with the Word of God rather than bodily food alone. Our nature is changeable and always capable of falling back; therefore, we must use this season to advance in virtue through a ready devotion and eager faith.
prayer: Almighty and most merciful God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ: We give You praise and hearty thanks for all Your goodness and tender mercies. Help us to treasure in our hearts all that our Lord has done for us; and enable us to show our thankfulness by lives that are given wholly to Your service.

title: Saturday after Ash Wednesday: The First Gospel
meditation: Though we are dust and to dust we must return, the Lord did not leave us in the power of the serpent. In the 'protoevangelium' or first gospel, God promised that the woman's Seed would crush the serpent's head, a victory won through the substitutionary death of Christ for lost sinners.
prayer: Lord God, heavenly Father, we confess that we are by nature sinful and come short of Your glory, daily and hourly sinning much in thought, word, and deed. Forgive the sins of every one among us, lay them not to our charge, but cover them with the merits of our Savior Jesus Christ and remember them no more in all eternity.

title: Lent 1 (Invocavit): Victory in Temptation
meditation: On this first Sunday in Lent, we see Christ overcome Satan in the wilderness, providing a paradigm for how we may approve ourselves in our own temptations. We draw strength and comfort from our Baptism, retorting to the accusations of the devil and our own conscience, 'But I am baptized!'.
prayer: O Lord, mercifully hear our prayer and stretch forth the right hand of Your majesty to defend us from those who rise up against us; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord, who lives and reigns with You and the Holy Spirit, ever one God, world without end.

title: Monday of Lent 1: The Ark of the Church
meditation: We confess that we are by nature sinful and have disobeyed God in thought, word, and deed, deserving His punishment. Yet, just as a few were saved in the ark, the Church remains the place where we take refuge from judgment and are preserved by the Holy Spirit.
prayer: Almighty God, merciful Father, who created and completed all things, on this day when the work of our calling begins anew, we implore You to create its beginning, direct its continuance, and bless its end, that our doings may be preserved from sin, our life sanctified, and our work this day be well pleasing to You; through Jesus Christ, our Lord.

title: Tuesday of Lent 1: The Branch of Peace
meditation: Even in the midst of trials, the Father remembers His holy covenant and establishes a lasting relationship through the blood sacrifice of the Messiah. To the yearning heart, God's absolution is as welcome and refreshing as the young olive branch the dove brought to Noah to signal the end of wrath.
prayer: Lord God, heavenly Father, who does not take pleasure in the miserable sinners’ death, nor willingly permits them to perish, but desires that they become converted and live: We humbly pray You, that You will graciously turn away from us the well-deserved punishment for our sins, and, in order to our improvement henceforth, graciously grant us Your mercy.

title: Wednesday of Lent 1: The Patience of God
meditation: As the waters of the flood recede, we see God's heart of patience toward a fallen creation. Just as the soil receives the seed in Christ's parable, we are called to receive the Word of God not with the hard heart of the wayside, but with a spirit that recognizes God's long-suffering mercy toward sinners.
prayer: Lord God, heavenly Father, You know that because of our human weakness we are not able to stand fast amid so many and great dangers: Grant us strength both in body and soul, that, by Your help, we may conquer all things which harass us because of our sins, for Jesus Christ our Lord’s sake.

title: Thursday of Lent 1: The Sign of the Bow
meditation: The rainbow is a sign of a covenant established not by our merit, but by God's promise. When storms of life and conscience arise, and we feel we are perishing like the disciples on the sea, we look to the cross-the ultimate sign that God is at peace with us and will never let the floods of judgment overwhelm those in Christ.
prayer: Blessed Lord Jesus Christ, at this hour You hung upon the cross, stretching out Your loving arms to embrace the world in Your death. Grant that all people of the earth may look to You and see their salvation; for Your mercy's sake we pray.

title: Friday of Lent 1: The Confusion of Babel
meditation: Humanity seeks to build its own way to heaven through works and pride, only to find confusion and scattering. In contrast, Christ enters the 'abyss' of our madness and possession to bring the peace of His Word. True unity is found not in human projects, but in being gathered by the Spirit into the Body of Christ.
prayer: O Lord Jesus, who has made it my lot to bear the cross, give me also an obedient and submissive heart that I may willingly take Your yoke upon me and follow You in every affliction.

title: Saturday of Lent 1: The Call of Abram
meditation: Abram is called to go out into the unknown, relying solely on God's Word. This is the life of faith: reaching out to touch the hem of Christ's garment in the midst of the crowd. Like the daughter of Jairus, we are dead in our trespasses until the Lord speaks His life-giving command, 'Arise!'
prayer: Gracious God, renew and refresh us with a gentle rain of Your grace. Bring to nothing all the counsels of darkness and keep us henceforth from evil; let us not become sluggish, but daily more spiritual and heavenly-minded for the sake of Your Son, our Savior.

title: Lent 2 (Reminiscere): Divine Strength in Weakness
meditation: True prayer does not arise from our own worthiness or inherent strength, but from an earnest cry in the face of distress. We are like Sarah, who laughed at the impossible, yet God is faithful to His promise. In our weakness, we find that God's strength is sufficient, and He provides for us even in the 'deserted places' of our lives.
prayer: O God, who sees that of ourselves we have no strength: Keep us both outwardly and inwardly; that we may be defended from all adversities which may happen to the body, and from all evil thoughts which may assault and hurt the soul; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord.

title: Monday of Lent 2: The God Who Sees Me
meditation: Even when we are cast out or find ourselves in a wilderness of our own making, God hears the cry of the afflicted. As Christ feeds the five thousand in the wilderness, we learn that He is the host of the table who provides all that is necessary for our life and salvation, refusing to let the hungry faint by the way.
prayer: Lord Jesus, at this season of the year we meditate upon Your bitter suffering for our sins. Open to us the rich living well of comfort issuing forth from Your wounds and assure us that we are redeemed children of God because reconciliation has been effected by You.

title: Tuesday of Lent 2: The Ram Provided
meditation: On Mount Moriah, the ram caught in the thicket serves as a type of Christ, our substitute. The Father does not spare His own Son, but gives Him up for us all. We must beware of the 'doctrines of men' that seek to replace this substitutionary sacrifice with human traditions and outward washings that cannot cleanse the heart.
prayer: O Lord Jesus, who has redeemed us with Your blood, has called us by means of Baptism and the Word, and enlightened us with Your gifts, we pray You, also sanctify us and help us faithfully to fight against, and overcome, every enemy of our soul.

title: Wednesday of Lent 2: The Servant's Journey
meditation: God guides His servants according to His steadfast love and faithfulness. Just as the Syrophoenician woman persisted in her prayer, clinging to the 'crumbs' of the promise, we are encouraged to remain steadfast in faith. Christ opens our ears to hear His promise and looses our tongues to confess His mercy.
prayer: Almighty God, our heavenly Father, who desires not the death of a sinner, but rather that he should turn from his evil way and live: we beseech You graciously to turn from us those punishments which we by our sins have deserved and to grant us grace ever hereafter to serve You in holiness and pureness of living.

title: Thursday of Lent 2: The Blessing Bestowed
meditation: The union of Isaac and Rebekah points toward the mystery of Christ and His Church. However, we are often slow to understand, like the disciples who worried about bread after seeing the four thousand fed. We must look beyond the physical elements to the Giver of the Bread of Life, who satisfies the soul's hunger.
prayer: O Lord, we beseech You mercifully to receive the prayers of Your people who call upon You; and grant that they may both perceive and know what things they ought to do, and also may have grace and power faithfully to fulfill the same; through Jesus Christ, our Lord.

title: Friday of Lent 2: The Stolen Blessing
meditation: In the account of Jacob and Esau, we see the messiness of human sin and the struggle for the blessing. To follow Christ is to take up the cross and lose one's life for His sake. We are blind to the true nature of God's kingdom until Christ touches us a second time, opening our eyes to see the suffering Son of Man.
prayer: Almighty and everlasting God, who governs all things in heaven and earth: mercifully look upon our infirmities, and in all our dangers and necessities stretch forth the right hand of Your Majesty to help and defend us; through Jesus Christ, our Lord.

title: Saturday of Lent 2: The Gate of Heaven
meditation: Jacob's ladder is the communication between heaven and earth, fulfilled in the Person of Jesus Christ. On the Mount of Transfiguration, we see the glory of the Son, but we are commanded to listen to Him as He descends to the cross. He is the only ladder by which we may ascend to the Father.
prayer: O Lord, we beseech You to keep Your Church and household continually in Your true religion that they who do lean upon the hope of Your heavenly grace may evermore be defended by Your mighty power; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord.

title: Lent 3 (Oculi): Eyes Fixed on the Hidden God
meditation: To be a 'theologian of the cross' is to see God not in majesty or power, but in suffering and the shame of Calvary. We pray for the Holy Spirit to enlighten our minds so that, even when faced with the overwhelming power of the devil, we cry out with the father of the boy, 'Lord, I believe; help my unbelief!'
prayer: We beseech You, Almighty God, look upon the hearty desires of Your humble servants and stretch forth the right hand of Your majesty to be our defense against all our enemies; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord, who lives and reigns with You and the Holy Spirit, ever one God, world without end.

title: Monday of Lent 3: The Struggle for the Household
meditation: True greatness in the kingdom of God is found in being the servant of all. As Jacob is called to return to the land of his kindred, we are called to walk in our vocations with humility. If our hands or feet cause us to stumble by leading us into pride or self-interest, the Word of the Law cuts them away so that we may enter life whole.
prayer: O Lord Jesus, who took the form of a servant for our sake, pour into our hearts the spirit of true humility. Grant that we may serve our neighbors with a willing mind and keep our eyes turned from the vanities of this world, looking only to You for our reward.

title: Tuesday of Lent 3: Wrestling with God
meditation: Jacob wrestles with the Angel and refuses to let go until he receives a blessing. This is the struggle of faith: clinging to God's promise even when He seems to be our adversary. We come to Him with the simplicity of children, for to such belongs the kingdom-not because of their strength, but because they simply receive the blessing given.
prayer: Lord, Almighty God, who does not disdain the sighs of the forlorn, and does not despise the longing of troubled hearts: O look upon our prayer, which we bring before You in our need, and graciously hear us, so that all which strives against us, both of the devil and of man, may come to nothing.

title: Wednesday of Lent 3: The Pit of Betrayal
meditation: As Joseph is sold into slavery by his brothers, we see a shadow of the Son of Man who came to His own and His own received Him not. Yet, what men meant for evil, God meant for good-using the betrayal and suffering of His Son to provide a way of escape for all who are enslaved by the famine of sin.
prayer: Lord, our God, we can properly address You as our dear Father only if we keep ourselves separate from the unbelieving world, following a different rule and standard, leading a different life, so that we can truthfully say: 'The world is crucified to me and I to the world.'

title: Thursday of Lent 3: Receiving Like a Child
meditation: The Lord was with Joseph in the house of Potiphar, and He is with us in our own stations of life. To enter the kingdom of God, we must set aside the pride of our achievements and receive the Word as a child receives a gift. The first shall be last, and the last first, for the kingdom belongs to those who trust solely in the Giver.
prayer: Lord Jesus, graciously show us the errors and perils into which we have fallen and bring us back to what is right. If penalty and pain must follow upon sin, let us suffer here, but spare us yonder. Yea, help us, Lord, to finish the race and keep the faith to the end.

title: Friday of Lent 3: The Ransom for Many
meditation: In the prison of Egypt, Joseph interprets dreams of life and death, but Christ enters the prison of our mortality to bring absolute life. He goes before us to Jerusalem, not to take a throne of earthly glory, but to give His life as a ransom for many. Like Bartimaeus, we cry out for mercy, and the Lord opens our eyes to see the Way of the Cross.
prayer: Lord Jesus, again we have assembled to deliberate upon congregational affairs. We pray You above all, enable us to discern what is right and wholesome, zealously to perform it, and with Your help to bring everything to a proper termination.

title: Saturday of Lent 3: The King in Meekness
meditation: Joseph is raised from the dungeon to the palace to preserve life, a type of Christ's exaltation for our salvation. As Jesus enters Jerusalem on a beast of burden, He shows that His kingdom is not of this world's violence, but of the Word's power. He cleanses the temple of our hearts so that they may become houses of prayer rather than dens of thieves.
prayer: Grant, we beseech You, that Your call to repent and to prepare for death may be spurned by none of us, but that we may all take refuge in Jesus Christ, cling to Him day and night, and finally depart in peace.

title: Lent 4 (Laetare): The Feast in the Famine
meditation: Mid-Lent brings a glimpse of joy, even as we continue to fast. We are like the world seeking bread from Joseph; we find that our true Brother, Jesus, has stored up an inexhaustible supply of grace. By the authority of His Cross, He feeds the hungry soul and provides the 'happy exchange' where our debt is canceled and His righteousness is given.
prayer: Grant, we beseech You, Almighty God, that we, who for our evil deeds do worthily deserve to be punished, by the comfort of Your grace may mercifully be relieved; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord, who lives and reigns with You in the unity of the Holy Spirit, God, forever and ever.

title: Monday of Lent 4: The Recognition of the Brother
meditation: Jacob's sons do not recognize Joseph, just as the builders of Israel rejected the Cornerstone. Yet the very stone the builders rejected has become the head of the corner. Our Lord uses the law to bring us to the same point of contrition as Joseph's brothers, that He might finally reveal Himself to us not as a judge, but as our Savior and Brother.
prayer: Keep, we beseech You, O Lord, Your Church with Your perpetual mercy; and, because the frailty of man without You we cannot but fall, keep us ever by Your help from all things hurtful, and lead us to all things profitable to our salvation; through Jesus Christ, our Lord.

title: Tuesday of Lent 4: To Whom Much is Forgiven
meditation: We often try to pay our own way before God, bringing 'double money' in our hands as if to buy His favor. But God is not the God of the dead, but of the living. He requires no payment from us, for Christ has rendered unto God the perfect obedience we could not. We live because He is the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and His promise is surer than death.
prayer: Lord Jesus, this sacred season brings to our remembrance how You assumed our flesh and blood. Weighed down by the burden of our guilt, You brought us freedom from sin. Grant us grace constantly to seek the rich treasures of Your grace and lay hold on You by faith.

title: Wednesday of Lent 4: The Sacrifice of Love
meditation: Judah offers himself as a substitute for his brother Benjamin, a moving image of the one who would come from his line. Christ is the true substitute who loves God with all His heart and His neighbor as Himself, giving not out of His abundance, but giving His very life-all that He had-to redeem His brethren from the silver cup of judgment.
prayer: Absolve, we beseech You, O Lord, Your people from their offenses; that from the bonds of our sins which, by reason of our frailty, we have brought upon us, we may be delivered by Your bountiful goodness; through Jesus Christ, our Lord.

title: Thursday of Lent 4: The End of the Temple
meditation: As Joseph finally reveals his identity and forgives his brothers, the old order of fear passes away. Jesus warns that the magnificent stones of the temple will be cast down, directing our faith away from external structures to the temple of His Body. In the midst of tribulations and false christs, we hold fast to the Word that does not pass away.
prayer: Almighty God, who into the place of the traitor Judas chose Your faithful servant Matthias, grant that Your Church, ever being preserved from false apostles, may continually abide in the doctrine of Your true Apostles; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord.

title: Friday of Lent 4: Tending the Promise
meditation: Jacob finds rest in Egypt under the protection of his son, just as we find rest in this world under the shadow of the cross. We wait for the Son of Man to come in the clouds with great power and glory. Lent is a season of 'staying awake,' keeping watch over our hearts through prayer and the Word, lest the Master find us sleeping in carnal security.
prayer: O almighty God, who has enriched Your Church with the precious Gospel written by Your Evangelist Saint Mark, give us grace that we may firmly believe Your glad tidings of salvation and daily walk as it becomes the Gospel of Christ.

title: Saturday of Lent 4: The Scepter of Judah
meditation: Jacob dies in hope, looking for the Shiloh to whom the obedience of the people belongs. In the house at Bethany, Mary anoints Jesus for His burial, recognizing the King who wins His kingdom by dying. While some grumble at the 'waste,' faith sees the beauty of the sacrifice that prepares the way for the ultimate Passover.
prayer: O God, who gave Your Apostles Peter and Paul grace to lay down their lives for the sake of Your dear Son, endow us with like constancy that we may at all times be ready to lay down our lives for Him who laid down His life for us.

title: Lent 5 (Judica): Our High Priest and Sacrifice
meditation: As the season enters its most solemn phase, we see the battle lines drawn. Egypt seeks to destroy the children of promise, but God prepares a deliverer. In the Upper Room, Christ institutes the new testament in His blood. He is the High Priest who enters the Holy of Holies not with the blood of goats, but with His own blood, offered once for all for our vindication.
prayer: We beseech You, Almighty God, mercifully to look upon Your people, that by Your great goodness they may be governed and preserved evermore, both in body and soul; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord, who lives and reigns with You in the unity of the Holy Spirit, God, forever and ever.

title: Monday of Lent 5: The Agony in the Garden
meditation: Moses is drawn from the water to save his people, but Christ enters the 'deep waters' of Gethsemane to save the world. He prays that the cup might pass, yet submits to the Father's will. In His agony, He is left alone as His disciples sleep, bearing the full weight of human abandonment so that we might never be forsaken by God.
prayer: Almighty eternal God, by whose Spirit the whole body of the Church is sanctified and ruled: Hear our supplications for all orders, that by the gift of Your grace You may be served by all these in pure faith; through Jesus Christ, our Lord.

title: Tuesday of Lent 5: The Great Confession
meditation: God speaks to Moses from the burning bush, revealing His name: 'I AM.' Before the high priest, Jesus confesses the same divine glory, declaring that they will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power. Though Peter denies Him with an oath, Christ's faithful confession stands as the bedrock of our hope and the source of our forgiveness.
prayer: Lord Jesus, grant us strength to keep in subjection our sinful flesh, which is inclined to all that is evil, and grant us Your Spirit in ever richer measure that we may joyfully and firmly confess that Your Word is the truth.

title: Wednesday of Lent 5: The King of the Jews
meditation: Moses is given signs to prove his mission, but Christ Himself is the sign. Before Pilate, He is silent like a lamb led to the slaughter. The world chooses Barabbas, the insurrectionist, while the innocent King of the Jews is delivered to be crucified. This is the mystery of the Gospel: the guilty go free because the Holy One is condemned in their place.
prayer: Grant, we beseech You, Almighty God, that we, who amid so many adversities do fail through our own infirmities, may be restored through the Passion and Intercession of Your only-begotten Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.

title: Thursday of Lent 5: The Mockery of the King
meditation: Moses returns to Egypt to face Pharaoh, but Christ goes to the cross to face the prince of this world. Cloaked in purple and crowned with thorns, He is mocked by the soldiers. He saves others, but Himself He cannot save-for if He saved Himself, we would be lost. He bears the shame of the cross to clothe us in the robes of His righteousness.
prayer: Grant, we beseech You, Almighty God, that we, who for our evil deeds are continually afflicted, may mercifully be relieved by the Passion of Your only-begotten Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.

title: Friday of Lent 5: The Death of the Son
meditation: As Pharaoh increases the burden on Israel, the darkness of the cross increases the burden on Christ. At the ninth hour, He cries out in dereliction and breathes His last. The centurion confesses, 'Truly this man was the Son of God!' In His death, the veil of the temple is rent, and the way into the presence of God is opened for all who believe.
prayer: Grant, O Lord, that, as Your Apostle Saint James readily obeyed the calling of Your Son Jesus Christ, we may by Your grace be enabled to forsake all worldly and carnal affections and to follow Him alone.

title: Saturday of Lent 5: The Rest of the Grave
meditation: The plagues begin to fall on Egypt, signaling the coming redemption. Christ rests in the tomb on the Sabbath, having completed His work of the new creation. The women find the stone rolled away, for death could not hold the Author of Life. We wait at the threshold of Easter, knowing that the tomb is no longer a place of despair, but the gate to eternal life.
prayer: Almighty God, who through Your Son Jesus Christ chose Saint Bartholomew to be an Apostle to preach the blessed Gospel, give to Your Church evermore faithful teachers to proclaim the glory of Your name.

title: Palm Sunday (Palmarum): The Lowly Triumph
meditation: The King comes to His city, not on a warhorse, but on a donkey. He is the Son who is the radiance of the Father's glory, yet He humbles Himself to the point of death. The crowds shout 'Hosanna!'-'Save now!'-unaware that His salvation will be won through the shame of the cross. We join their song, welcoming the one who comes to die that we might live.
prayer: Almighty and everlasting God, who sent Your Son, our Savior Jesus Christ, to take upon Himself our flesh, and to suffer death upon the Cross, that all mankind should follow the example of His great humility: Mercifully grant that we may follow the example of His patience and also be partakers of His resurrection.

title: Monday of Holy Week: The Fragrance of the Cross
meditation: Mary anoints Jesus with costly oil, filling the house with a fragrance that points to His burial. Christ is the captain of our salvation who was made perfect through suffering. He shared in our flesh and blood so that through death He might destroy the one who has the power of death, that is, the devil, and deliver all those who through fear of death were subject to lifelong slavery.
prayer: Almighty God, grant us grace so to pass through this holy time of our Lord's Passion that we may obtain the pardon of our sins; through Jesus Christ, Your Son, our Lord, who lives and reigns with You and the Holy Spirit, ever one God, world without end.

title: Tuesday of Holy Week: The Life-Giving Grain
meditation: Unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it bears much fruit. Christ is the true grain of wheat who died to bring forth the harvest of the Church. We are called to hold fast our confidence and the rejoicing of our hope firm unto the end, looking not to the signs of this world, but to the Light who has come into the darkness.
prayer: Lord God, heavenly Father, look on our neediness with the eyes of Your mercy and compassion. Rescue us from everything that would cause harm and destruction to us both physically and spiritually, and keep us in the true faith.

title: Wednesday of Holy Week: The Great High Priest
meditation: As darkness covers Egypt, the darkness of the Passion begins. We have a great High Priest who is able to sympathize with our weaknesses, having been tempted in every way as we are, yet without sin. We draw near to the throne of grace with confidence, for Christ has entered the sanctuary of the cross to make intercession for us, turning our judgment into a declaration of peace.
prayer: Almighty God, we beseech You graciously to behold this Your family, for which our Lord Jesus Christ was content to be betrayed and given up into the hands of wicked men and to suffer death upon the cross.

title: Maundy Thursday: The Testament of Peace
meditation: On the night He was betrayed, Christ instituted the Sacrament of His Body and Blood-the New Testament in His blood for the remission of sins. He washes the feet of His disciples, showing the depth of His humility. This feast is the medicine of immortality, provided for the comfort and strengthening of those who humbly confess their sins and hunger for righteousness.
prayer: O Lord God, who has left to us in a wonderful Sacrament a memorial of Your Passion: Grant, we beseech You, that we may so use this Sacrament of Your Body and Blood that the fruits of Your redemption may continually be manifest in us.

title: Good Friday: The Lamb Slain
meditation: The Passover is fulfilled as the true Lamb of God is sacrificed. On the cross, Jesus is 'numbered among the transgressors,' bearing the shame and the wrath we deserved. The 'old evil foe' is overcome by the very tree on which he thought he had triumphed. We look upon the Pierced One and find there the anchor of our soul, sure and steadfast, reaching into the presence of God.
prayer: Merciful and everlasting God, who has not spared Your only Son, but delivered Him up for us all, that He might bear our sins upon the Cross: Grant that our hearts may be so fixed with steadfast faith in Him that we may not fear the power of any adversaries.

title: Holy Saturday: The Sabbath of the Grave
meditation: Christ rests from His work of redemption in the quiet of the tomb. He has descended into hell to proclaim His victory over the powers of darkness. We wait in the silence, remembering our Baptism-the watery grave where we died with Christ so that we might also rise with Him. The pillar of cloud and fire guides us through the night of death toward the dawn of the new creation.
prayer: O God, who enlightened this most holy night with the glory of the Lord's Resurrection: Preserve in all Your people the spirit of adoption which You have given, so that renewed in body and soul they may perform to You a pure service.

title: Easter Sunday: The Day of Victory
meditation: Hallelujah! Christ is risen! The Red Sea of judgment has been crossed, and the enemy is drowned in the waters. Christ, our immortal High Priest, has passed through death into life, and because He lives, we also shall live. The Lenten fast is over; the feast of victory has begun. We are no longer dead in our sins, but alive in Christ, the firstfruits of all who have fallen asleep.
prayer: Almighty God, who through Your only-begotten Son, Jesus Christ, has overcome death and opened to us the gate of everlasting life: We humbly beseech You that, as You put into our minds good desires, so by Your continual help we may bring the same to good effect; through Jesus Christ, our Lord. Amen.
